Now I get the following error:  ![native-module-error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/434140/11419783/c1696724-947d-11e5-8d1e-bd5d4e564ff5.png)  Are native modules not supported in extensions?

**The good:** Nothing really. **The bad:** Code extensions unfortunately don't support native extensions. **The ugly:** There is a workaround. Bear with me: - Your native packages must be compiled against the exact same version of node and v8 that Code is. [Specifically](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/scripts/npm.sh):   - `npm_config_disturl=https://atom.io/download/atom-shell`   - `npm_config_target=` whatever value is there on [`electronVersion`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/package.json)   - `npm_config_arch=` whatever the bit architecture you need   - `HOME=` something other that `~`, like `~/.electron-gyp`, so node-gyp and npm don't confuse themselves. - The extension package must contain the binaries for _all_ platforms Code supports: `win32-ia32`, `darwin`, `linux-ia32` and `linux-x64`. It would then dynamically require the correct binary for the running platform at runtime. [bindings](https://www.npmjs.com/package/bindings) might help you there.
That's why a ponyfill comes in handy :). It uses the native promises if they are available, if not it will use the polyfill.   Example: [pinkie-promise](https://github.com/floatdrop/pinkie-promise)

I've analysed the problem and found this:  The source maps in our extensions 'out' folder have broken paths in their "sources" array. Normally these path entries should point to the source relative from the sourcemap location. But for the Monaco workspace these paths are relative to some other location. This makes it difficult for node-debug to figure out where the source lives. I can add more "guessing" heuristics to node-debug, but I think we should fix the root of the problem as well.  Here is an example from the typescript extension's "bufferSyncSupport":  - source: vscode/extensions/typescript/**src**/features/bufferSyncSupport.ts - dest: vscode/extensions/typescript/**out**/features/bufferSyncSupport.js  Since the sourcemap lives next to the destination file, the minimal relative path between map and source is "../../src/features/bufferSyncSupport.js".  However the actual path in the sources array is "../../vscode/extensions/typescript/src/features/bufferSyncSupport.ts".  If I run tsc in the typescript extension folder manually, the path in the source map is correct. Only the build watcher creates a broken path.  @joaomoreno, could it be that some gulp script is massaging the paths in the source maps?
